body:
@rdblue close to what I had locally, worked for me!

It would be also helpful to have access to `TableMetadata` for SS. `Table$snapshots` provides no guarantees about the order and returns snapshots starting from the first one. To find the latest committed `epochId`, it would make sense to iterate the snapshot lineage backwards starting from the most recent one. In most cases, we would stop after a couple of iterations. `TableMetadata` has enough information. Do we consider it as private API? There is no way to easily retrieve it, right? It can be accessed through `BaseTable`
We should be able to use the Table API to traverse all of the snapshots. You can get all the snapshots with `table.snapshots` then index by the ID, and traverse using `current.parentId()`.
Yeah, that's what I actually did, was worried about redoing the same work twice. I hope iterating through snapshots won't become a bottleneck in the commit phase.
We could expose the lookup function directly so we don't have to index.

Looks like in the first code path maybe just making `ParquetProperties` configurable instead of hardcoded and then for the second code path using the various builder methods to page size/dictionary size. I'll submit a PR.
I am +1 on this. @rdblue what do you think?

I definitely agree about minimizing the use of deprecated APIs that we know will be a problem for people that upgrade.

My concern about upgrading the version we use is that it could cause problems downstream. Do we expect everyone to shade guava? Also, now that we are using Caffeine, should we consider moving off of Guava?

I think we mainly use Guava for 4 things:
* Caches - replaced by Caffeine
* Iterables and Iterators
* Preconditions - easily replaced
* Maps, Lists, etc. for new and immutable containers

If we can find a good alternative for iterables/iterators that hopefully doesn't require too much of the streams API, maybe we should consider using that. We could also build alternatives of those for Iceberg; we already have a fair number of them in `CloseableIterable`.
Thanks for working on this, @ryanrupp! It looks close, but there are a few things to fix.
Not sure if you squash merge in this project but I can rebase/squash the commits down after review. Kept them separate to see the post review change set.

> My concern about upgrading the version we use is that it could cause problems downstream

Could we shade our Guava dependency in our artifacts?  We'd have to make sure that guava is bundled in our artifacts and shaded and is not fetched transitively, whereas the rest of the dependencies can be fetched transitively.  Shadow plugins allows us to do this. This could be some work and could change how our artifacts are fetched . Users would have to rely on the different classifier or configuration for the artifacts for example.
Sounds like something we might be interested in as well. Can you add more detail as to how you envision this will be used?

I have a working prototype. How do we want to handle `OutputMode.Complete()` in Structured Streaming? Right now, I am using `OverwriteFiles` to remove all existing files and append new ones. The retry logic seems to fit as well.

We could do something similar to what Avro and Parquet do -- build a shaded Jar and rewrite everything to depend on that. I'd rather not do that if we can cleanly move off of Guava, though. Does anyone agree with the idea of trying to move off?
`OutputMode.Complete` should replace all rows in the table using `OverwriteByExpression` with `true`.
We squash and merge to commit changes to master, so no need to squash here. My general rule is to do whatever you think makes the PR easiest to review.
Merged. Thanks @casidiablo!
Merging. Thanks for the review, @aokolnychyi!
+1 from me! Thanks for fixing this, @ryanrupp!
I am using `OverwriteFiles$overwriteByRowFilter` with `Expressions.alwaysTrue()`. Is it what you meant?
Do you mean building alternatives ourselves?

I think it is possible to leverage the snapshot log in Iceberg to use Iceberg tables as streaming sources for Structured Streaming. This would mean streaming out data from all of the files present in the table as well as from new files that arrive after the stream is started.

There are some things to think about:
- What should happen if we detect deleted files while we are streaming data out?
- What do we consider as one batch? For example, we will need to stream out data from all of the files present in the table when we start a query. This might be a lot of data, so we need to split it into multiple batches. The split can be based on either the number of files/records or even estimated size.
@prodeezy would you be interested to work on this?
Thanks, @rdblue! Mind rebasing? I think it is a nice feature to have!

@manishmalhotrawork The issue is more generic than just adding the dependency on `commons-io`. It is necessary to enable check during the build that all modules declare used dependencies and do not rely on transitive dependencies.
Will do, thanks for pinging me on it.
@rdblue addressed all but one comments. Need some clarification/guidance on evaluating position for the bound exp reference.
@samarthjain, did you intend to add the offsets in this PR?
I took another glance. Think i'v addressed all pending comments.  @rdblue
Will reopen a new PR since the branching got messed up on this one.

I have deliberately left the Tables interface and implementation for BaseMetaStore tables as we have not decided what are we going to do about the transaction APIs. We can either take this PR as an opportunity to address that or move those APIs under BaseMetastoreCatalog and remove Tables interface and all of its implementation.

For preconditions and iterators/iterables, we would probably build alternatives. A lot of those are already implemented in `CloseableIterables`. Preconditions are easy to add, too.

The main annoyance is the container types, including immutable variants. Is there an alternative for those?

To be clear I think it's appropriate to use Guava's APIs that are marked as stable, not deprecated, and not experimental / beta. Guava should be committed to API stability and thus it shouldn't be a problem if the Guava dependency is swapped from under the hood.

The issue is that we were using deprecated methods that were removed.

I wonder if we can add a linting check for this.
@aokolnychyi, sorry for the late reply. Yes, that's what I think it should do.
Looks mostly good, but needs to be rebased after #184 is committed, and I think we need to rename `offsetRanges` to `splitOffsets`.
Looks interesting to me to work on! I'm currently discussing this internally for approval.
Can you rebase on the current master to remove the commits from #184?
@omalley, I think this ORC PR is ready to go in. It updates the license headers for ORC files from Hortonworks to the standard ASF header. Could you reply with +1 or -1 for that change?

> Can you rebase on the current master to remove the commits from #184 

Done.

+1

thanks @edgarRd for fixing up the ORC bindings
Merged! Thanks for working on the ORC support, @edgarRd!
@samarthjain, I think that @rdsr is right about the method names that should be updated. Otherwise, it looks good. When updating the metrics, could you also fix the minor formatting that I noted?
Great, thanks all for the help!

+1

Thanks for contributing this, @samarthjain!

I'll merge after tests pass.
After a little searching, I don't see good alternatives for the immutable collections. I think we should move forward with upgrading Guava and not using deprecated methods.
+1 from me, and @rdsr already added a +1, so I'm going to merge this.
@prodeezy sure, let me know the outcome.

@danielcweeks @prodeezy @rdblue I've updated the benchmarking code and removed the results. Please, let me know what you think.

I am not sure we want to publicly document these benchmarks right now. I think it would make more sense once we have separate benchmarks for the Parquet reader/writer. At this point, Javadoc for each benchmark describes how it can be executed.

Another point to consider is how we compute diffs between snapshots. This operation should be efficient. For example, we consumed all of the data at a given point in time and then a new batch came in. We should be able to identify new files easily.
Do we see the new `Catalog` API as a better version of the `Tables` API that would be used in data sources?

I would totally support this effort. The benchmarks in [this PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/105) also confirm that vectorized execution is important.

I should mention that Iceberg's Parquet reader seems to be significantly more efficient on nested data.

I would certainly review and collaborate on this!

@aokolnychyi Spark disables vectorized read on nested data, which would then indicate that Iceberg without vectorized read is faster than Spark without vectorized read.

@mccheah you are right that we don't have vectorized reads on nested data in Spark. The benchmarks in the PR above test vectorized and non-vectorized reads on flat and nested data. On flat data, Iceberg is slightly faster. The real difference is seen on nested data. 

As I also said in that PR, Iceberg DS is V2 and the file source is still V1, which complicates the comparison. I am working on benchmarks for readers alone without Spark.
@rdblue gentle reminder. Lemme know if this looks ok to you.
Thanks for the reminder. I should have time to review it this week. Sorry for the delay.

It would be great to have people working on this! Feel free to pick it up and I'll help review it. I think there are good tests that we can copy that are used to validate the row-based readers and writers.

@julienledem may also be interested. He has given talks on how to efficiently deserialize Parquet to Arrow and can hopefully help answer questions.

For anyone interested, Spark already has a good reference implementation in Scala here: https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/arrow/ArrowWriter.scala

One thing to note is that there isn't an implementation for map type.  I think Arrow was planning on using list<struct<key,value>, but engines may need something closer to struct<keys:list<>, values:list<>> in order overlay the columnar implementations directly.  It might be necessary to provide both.

I'm happy to help anyone who's interested in working on this.

@aokolnychyi I just made a pull request for a schema converter between iceberg and arrow, which is the first step in getting setup for building vectors: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/194

Thanks @danielcweeks ! I also found https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/arrow/ArrowConverters.scala that has some nice plumbing for Batch to `Iterator[InternalRow]` and vice versa.  This is used by Spark's `Dataset` to convert partition/split data into Arrow Batch Rdds.

Another point about the current reader is that we first construct `GenericInternalRow`s and then have an unsafe projection to get `UnsafeRow`s. 

Here are benchmark results for readers/writers alone (without Spark):

```
Benchmark                                                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetReadersFlatDataBenchmark.readUsingIcebergReader                          ss    5  7.336 ± 0.298   s/op
SparkParquetReadersFlatDataBenchmark.readUsingIcebergReaderUnsafe                    ss    5  8.533 ± 0.237   s/op
SparkParquetReadersFlatDataBenchmark.readUsingSparkReader                            ss    5  9.859 ± 0.335   s/op

Benchmark                                                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetReadersFlatDataBenchmark.readWithProjectionUsingIcebergReader            ss    5  3.964 ± 0.140   s/op
SparkParquetReadersFlatDataBenchmark.readWithProjectionUsingIcebergReaderUnsafe      ss    5  5.032 ± 0.061   s/op
SparkParquetReadersFlatDataBenchmark.readWithProjectionUsingSparkReader              ss    5  5.076 ± 0.181   s/op

Benchmark                                                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetReadersNestedDataBenchmark.readUsingIcebergReader                        ss    5  3.925 ± 0.225   s/op
SparkParquetReadersNestedDataBenchmark.readUsingIcebergReaderUnsafe                  ss    5  4.514 ± 0.097   s/op
SparkParquetReadersNestedDataBenchmark.readUsingSparkReader                          ss    5  5.673 ± 0.194   s/op

Benchmark                                                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetReadersNestedDataBenchmark.readWithProjectionUsingIcebergReader          ss    5  1.914 ± 0.126   s/op
SparkParquetReadersNestedDataBenchmark.readWithProjectionUsingIcebergReaderUnsafe    ss    5  2.408 ± 0.058   s/op
SparkParquetReadersNestedDataBenchmark.readWithProjectionUsingSparkReader            ss    5  2.682 ± 0.165   s/op

Benchmark                                                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetWritersFlatDataBenchmark.writeUsingIcebergWriter                         ss    5  4.789 ± 0.168   s/op
SparkParquetWritersFlatDataBenchmark.writeUsingSparkWriter                           ss    5  4.948 ± 0.188   s/op

Benchmark                                                                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetWritersNestedDataBenchmark.writeUsingIcebergWriter                       ss    5  2.750 ± 0.184   s/op
SparkParquetWritersNestedDataBenchmark.writeUsingSparkWriter                         ss    5  2.859 ± 0.222   s/op
```

The code is available in the above PR.
I've implemented basic benchmarks for readers/writers. This PR is ready for the first review round.
@danielcweeks, can you take a look?
Thanks @rdsr! Can you add a test for this like the one for Parquet?
Merged. Thanks @aokolnychyi!

@rdblue I guess you mean this test [TestBasicWrite](https://github.com/samarthjain/incubator-iceberg/blob/007d85c162533601d5d4e8f11286185d8bdda851/spark/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/source/TestParquetWrite.java). The problem here is that I cannot simply update that test (to support both Parquet and ORC) as Spark write support for ORC is not available. I'll try to write a separate ORC standalone test similar to `TestBasicWrite` but without the Spark engine support. 

Thanks
Good point. Let's at least get some test in that validates we get the splits, but I see what you mean that we can't build an end-to-end test.
Thanks for adding this @rdsr. I assume that a test within the ORC package should be possible and validating that the splits are correctly retrieved.

On the other hand, I think this may be a separate question, but do we want write support in ORC at all? Or should we just remove all the code related to writes and just not support it in Iceberg?
I assume for most people the main use case would be to easily migrate existing ORC datasets, but moving forward to write in Parquet.

What do you think?

@prodeezy, I thought that it would be easier if I made a few minor changes since it would take longer to ask you to do them than to just move a few things around. I opened a PR against your branch: https://github.com/prodeezy/incubator-iceberg/pull/1

If you agree with those changes, just merge the PR and push and I'll commit this. Thanks!

Hi @edgarRd, my take would be to keep the write support we currently have. Different companies will have different preferences and if folks would like to contribute and improve ORC support, without negatively affecting the Iceberg abstractions/APIs,  we should allow that.  This could help Iceberg get more adoption and contributions.

I've completed the Java part locally. What do we do with Scala?
@rdblue @mccheah Which `scalastyle_config.xml` do we want to use? Spark?
Baseline has a `scalastyle` plugin: `com.palantir.baseline-scalastyle`. Can we apply that plugin and see how it lints the existing code?
@prodeezy, the test failures are because I removed the map column from `TestMetricsRowGroupFilter`. I thought that wasn't used but I guess it was. If you add that column back, the tests should pass.

I agree, there's no need to make that choice for people using Iceberg. If someone wants to use ORC, it should ideally work. But we need to get it to where we can guarantee the same behavior as the other formats.

> Do we see the new `Catalog` API as a better version of the `Tables` API that would be used in data sources?

Yes, for metastore use cases. `Tables` is still useful for path-based cases, like Hadoop tables and in Pig.

Yeah, I was aware this part of the code could be optimized. Originally I was thinking to refactor those converters to a set of visitors to convert the ORC row to InternalRow and avoid this building of the DAG of converters. Pretty much this is what is done in the Parquet reader as well.

What did you have in mind?
Unfortunately I don't think there is such a way, looking at the Baseline source code. I think putting the configuration under `project/scalastyle_config.xml` is fine.
Fixed test.
Merged! Thanks for fixing this @prodeezy!

@edgarRd, here's some rough code which passes the tests. https://github.com/rdsr/incubator-iceberg/commit/0b9bb24add8b25acb526e7179c4d02acef9fdf34 . I still have to verify whether the underlying approach is correct, given that the way I use `UnsafeWriter` in the code is very much different from yours
This one is done and is awaiting an open source approval.
Thanks @aokolnychyi for the comments. I've addressed all.
Thanks, @rdsr! There are two more places with `hiddenField`. I am not sure about the best naming there. Otherwise, LGTM.

I am wondering about the best way to implement this feature.

A few ideas that came to my mind are below.

**Option 1 (TableProperties)**

We will have to add multiple new properties.
For example, we might use something like this:

```
metrics.collection.enabled=true
metrics.collection.column-delimiter=,
metrics.collection.bounds.enabled=true
metrics.collection.bounds.columns=col1,col2.nested
```

This option is a bit cumbersome and might become tricky (e.g., we need to reason about expressing nested columns, etc). Instead of storing a list of columns, we can store a regular expression. 

Then we will be able to construct a `MetricsSpec` based on those properties and pass it to writers.

**Option 2 (Extend Metadata)**

Alternatively, we can store a `MetricsSpec` directly in the metadata (similar to `PartitionSpec`) and expose an API to update it. Also, users will be able to provide a correct `MetricsSpec` while creating tables. The design of `MetricsSpec` is an open question.

@rdblue any suggestions on this?

I'd prefer the simpler table property approach because it can be configured using existing SQL DDL (`SET TBLPROPERTIES`). Here's what I would do to keep the configuration small:

1. Define modes: `full`, `counts`, and `none` to express all metrics, just null/value counts, and no metrics
2. Allow setting a column default: `metadata.metrics.default=full`
3. Add column-level config: `metadata.metrics.column.(column-name)=counts` to allow per-column tuning

That way, the configuration stays simple and users can choose how to minimize the amount of configuration properties they need to set by controlling the default and then updating individual columns from there.
That's a clean way to control it! Let me go ahead and implement this.

Am I correct that this API reorders manifests and their content? `MergingSnapshotUpdate` keeps the ordering to efficiently age off data files. Do we expect users to apply this API to recent manifests on a regular basis if their writes frequently modify a lot of partitions?

Also, what will happen if our clustering key assigns a lot of files to one manifest?
Will `commit.manifest.target-size-bytes` be respected?

This will create entirely new manifests (with a new snapshot ID and with new contents) that replace existing manifests, so in essence, yes, the manifests and contents will be reordered. We were planning to apply this API on a regular basis on new manifests (e.g. hourly or daily). Also, `commit.manifest.target-size-bytes` will not be respected thus this could generate large manifest files.

I first thought of adding this functionality to `MergingSnapshotProducer` but this would either generate far too many manifests (trading long file scans for long manifest scans) or generate manifests with wide partition ranges as it does now.

Respecting `commit.manifest.target-size-bytes` should be straightforward if that is desired. I'm not sure how respecting manifest order is possible though.
@aokolnychyi, FYI.
@danielcweeks, can you review this?

Yeah, I also don't think it is possible to respect manifest order. I brought this topic to better understand the implications. It seems if we apply this regularly and incrementally we will still have some order. At some point, I was wondering about optionally optimizing the manifest layout while merging groups in `MergingSnapshotUpdate`. However, your idea seems better.

Respecting table properties would be nice, though.
I'll go ahead and add support for `commit.manifest.target-size-bytes` now...
I added the manifest size check. It doesn't appear that there is an easy way to get the bytes written by the ManifestWriter, so I'm using a size estimation.

One question I have is about config parameter names passed as options.
For now, we have `iceberg.write.format` and this PR adds `snapshot-id` and `as-of-timestamp`.
How do we see the style of passed options? Do we need `iceberg` prefix?
Merged. Thanks for fixing this, @samarthjain!
